def sort_colors(nums: list[int]) -> None:
    # Dutch National Flag algorithm
    # Three pointers: low, mid, high
    low = 0      # boundary for 0s
    mid = 0      # current element
    high = len(nums) - 1  # boundary for 2s
    
    while mid <= high:
        if nums[mid] == 0:
            # Swap with low boundary, advance both
            nums[low], nums[mid] = nums[mid], nums[low]
            low += 1
            mid += 1
        elif nums[mid] == 1:
            # 1 is in correct position, just advance
            mid += 1
        else:  # nums[mid] == 2
            # Swap with high boundary, only decrement high
            nums[mid], nums[high] = nums[high], nums[mid]
            high -= 1
            # Don't increment mid - need to check swapped value
hints: Use three pointers: low (0s boundary), mid (current), high (2s boundary)
Elements before low are all 0s, elements after high are all 2s
When you see 0, swap with low and advance both pointers
When you see 2, swap with high but only decrement high (need to check swapped value)
explanation: The Dutch National Flag algorithm uses three pointers. 'low' marks where the next 0 should go, 'high' marks where the next 2 should go, and 'mid' is the current element. When we see 0, swap it to the low section. When we see 2, swap it to the high section. When we see 1, leave it in place. Key insight: after swapping with high, don't advance mid because the swapped element hasn't been examined yet. Time: O(n), Space: O(1).
